I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Implemented under the overall guidance of the United Nations Statistical Commission 
(UNSC), the International Comparison Program (ICP) is the world’s largest statistical initiative. It 
aims  to  produce  globally  comparable  measures  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  and  its 
components (household consumption expenditure, government consumption expenditure, gross 
fixed capital formation, and imports and exports) based on purchasing power parities (PPPs) for 
economies  across  the  world.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  through  its  Economic 
Research and Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD), has been the regional implementing 
agency (RIA) of the ICP for Asia and the Pacific since 2003.1 For the 2005 and 2011 ICP 
benchmark rounds, ADB added value through successful coordination and producing regionally 
comparable PPPs required for estimating global PPPs.2 For the ongoing 2017 ICP, ADB’s Office 
of the Chief Economist and Director General—Statistics and Data Innovation Unit (EROD-SDI, 
ERCD) is the RIA for 22 participating economies.3 For the 2020 ICP cycle, which begins globally 
in January 2020, ADB will provide overall management, coordinate regional data collection in 
participating economies through the national implementing agencies (NIAs), validate and analyze 
data, and calculate the Asia and Pacific regional PPPs. The knowledge and support technical 
assistance (TA) aims to support ADB’s role as the RIA for the 2020 ICP in Asia and the Pacific to 
produce PPPs for 2020 and to undertake related statistical capacity-building initiatives. 
 
2.  The TA is part of the approved 2019 Work Plan of the ERCD and was endorsed as a 
corporate priority TA.4 It is linked to the Global Action Plan for Sustainable Development Data 
through Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) target 17.19, which aims to “build on existing 
initiatives to develop measurements of progress on sustainable development that complement 
GDP, and support statistical capacity building in developing countries.”5 The TA is aligned with 
ADB’s Strategy 2030, which envisions ADB’s increasing role as a knowledge institution in the 
region and in expanding knowledge partnerships and knowledge dissemination.6 
 
 
1  The ICP is a global partnership among national statistics offices (NSOs), the RIAs, and the World Bank, all sharing 
the responsibilities in the implementation process. More than 175 economies are participating in the ongoing 2017 
ICP cycle. The following agencies act as current RIAs and will continue to play their roles for the 2020 ICP cycle: the 
African Development Bank for Africa, ADB for Asia and the Pacific, The Interstate Statistical Committee of the 
Commonwealth of Independent States for Commonwealth of Independent States, the Economic Commission for 
Latin America and the Caribbean for Latin America and the Caribbean, the Economic Commission for West Asia for 
West Asia, The Statistical Office of the European Communities (Eurostat) and the Organisation for Economic Co-
operation and Development (OECD) for Euro area and OECD economies. The UNSC established an ICP Governing 
Board with members from 11 economies, RIAs, the World Bank, the United Nations Statistics Division, and the 
International Monetary Fund (IMF) to oversee the implementation of the global program.

II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Stakeholders  are  increasingly  demanding  more  frequent  PPP-based  comparable 
measures of economic output that are free of price and exchange rate distortions. The PPPs 
obtained through the ICP are used for direct comparisons of indicators of well-being such as per 
capita GDP or expenditures, per capita on health, education, and housing, among others, and 
thus allow for real comparisons of price levels and standards of living and well-being across 
economies.  The  PPPs  for  household  consumption  are  the  main  inputs  for  deriving  the 
international poverty line and updating the poverty headcounts used to monitor targets on global 
and regional poverty associated with the SDG agenda. Currently, the international poverty line, 
set at $1.90 per day, is based on the 2011 ICP PPPs. Apart from the use of the PPPs to monitor 
poverty, other PPP-based indicators in the SDG framework help monitor income inequality, 
energy intensity, labor productivity, carbon dioxide emissions per unit of GDP, etc. ADB’s policy 
paper ADB Corporate Results Framework, 2019–2024 is aligned with the SDG agenda and 
includes  indicators  that  track  development  progress  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific  and  whose 
measurement depends on PPPs.7 Other examples of international organizations that use PPPs 
include  the  Human  Development  Index  by  the  United  Nations  Development  Programme, 
assessment of per capita expenditures in education by the United Nations Educational, Scientific, 
and Cultural Organization, and calculation of special drawing rights and voting power of member 
countries by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) formula that includes GDP in PPP terms, 
among  other  variables.  Some  economies  adopt  ICP  principles  and  methods  to  produce 
subnational PPPs to compare standards of living across regions within an economy. 
 
4.  Until recently, the ICP was implemented at irregular benchmark years, with the last four 
rounds  in  1993,  2005,  2011,  and  2017.  PPP  estimates  for  non-benchmark  years  rely  on 
extrapolation techniques. Past lessons suggest that extrapolating PPPs for the years between 
benchmarks, especially when there is a long gap, has been problematic and leads to large 
differences between extrapolated PPPs and PPPs from the new benchmark. The extrapolation 
approach implicitly assumes that internationally comparable price indexes evolve identically with 
the national price indexes used for extrapolation. Comparability problems also arise because of 
methodological improvements in computing PPPs across ICP benchmark years. Consequently, 
the consistency between spatial and temporal indexes cannot be maintained over long periods, 
leading to major revisions in GDP expressed in PPP terms when ICP benchmark results become 
available. 
 
5.  To address these inconsistencies, the UNSC endorsed the ICP global comparisons as a 
permanent element of the global statistical work program in March 2016. The UNSC also 
endorsed a shortened interval of 3 years between ICP benchmark rounds, starting in 2017, to 
provide direct price comparisons more frequently. The ICP is a multilateral exercise implemented 
with  the  collaborative  participation  of  national  statistical  agencies,  regional  agencies,  and 
international development partners, who share the responsibility to collect, validate, and process 
data and estimate PPPs and other economic aggregates. This governance framework, with actors 
at national, regional, and global levels, makes the ICP a unique global statistical initiative and 
successfully led to the implementation of the 2005, 2011, and ongoing 2017 ICP rounds. 
 
6.  The ICP relies on the national statistics offices (NSOs) in each economy to serve as the 
NIAs. The NIAs collect prices of relevant items from a catalogue of more than a thousand 
comparable items (goods and services) that form part of the final expenditures in the GDP. The 
NSOs conduct ICP price surveys in addition to their regular price surveys for compiling consumer 
price indexes (CPIs). The items in the ICP and CPI baskets overlap only partially, so ICP price 
collection entails additional work for NSOs. Many NSOs lack adequate resources for ICP activities, 
 
7  ADB. 2019. ADB Corporate Results Framework, 2019–2024. Manila.

3 
which do not get same priority as CPI price surveys. Because the economies in the Asia and 
Pacific region have very diverse backgrounds and capacities, coordinating regional activities is 
complex  and  challenging,  requiring  TA  and  capacity-building  support  to  ensure  uniform 
compliance with the strict standards and protocols of ICP price surveys, especially in economies 
with weak statistical capacities and/or those with resource constraints. PPP computation also 
requires detailed disaggregation of GDP expenditures following ICP classification and the United 
Nations System of National Accounts 2008, which are used as weights in aggregating PPPs at 
higher levels. Integrating ICP and CPI price collection technically and operationally will help 
reduce the burden on limited NSO resources. With ICP becoming a regular activity, integrating 
CPI and ICP is likely to get more attention in coming years, despite the greater challenges in 
implementing it. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: utilization of comparable macroeconomic 
statistics in policy making and research enhanced.8 The TA will have the following outcome: 
comparability of macroeconomic aggregates for ADB member economies in Asia and the Pacific 
improved.9 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: International Comparison Program regional governance framework for 
Asia and the Pacific established. The regional governance framework for the 2020 ICP will 
follow the successful framework of earlier ICP rounds: (i) participating ADB member economies 
will sign a no-objection letter to participate in the TA, designating their NSOs or the agency 
responsible for price statistics or national accounts statistics as the NIAs to implement national 
level price activities; and (ii) a regional advisory board (RAB), which comprises NIA heads of 
select participating ADB member economies, ADB, and regional and international organizations 
and institutions, will endorse the policies and protocols for calculating regional PPPs for the 2020 
ICP for Asia and the Pacific.10 As the RIA, ADB will be a member in the ICP Governing Board and 
Interagency Coordination Group and collaborate with the ICP Global Office at the World Bank for 
ICP  implementation  conforming  to  the  standard  concepts  and  methodology  of  this  global 
exercise.11 
 
9.  Output 2: International Comparison Program survey tools developed and price 
surveys conducted. The TA will develop ICP survey data tools required for ICP implementation 
and conduct price surveys with:  
(i)  ICP 2020 product catalogs with structured product descriptions for household 
goods  and  services  (including  dwelling  services)  to  collect  nationally 
representative prices of household consumption, items of construction inputs

10.  Output 3: International Comparison Program knowledge products delivered and

(i)  datasets of validated annual national average ICP item prices, regional PPPs, and 
real GDP expenditures for each participating economy, disaggregated by 155 
basic headings and at higher level aggregates for 22 ADB member economies 
expected to participate in the 2020 ICP cycle under ADB’s TA;12 
(ii)  a final regional report, titled “2020 International Comparison Program for Asia and 
the Pacific: Purchasing Power Parities and Real Expenditures,” that will include 
conceptual, methodological, and operational aspects of ICP implementation, and 
2020 ICP regional results with PPPs and PPP-based estimates of GDP and its 
components;  
(iii)  methodological research on enhanced uses of PPPs at the national level (such as 
subnational  PPP  compilation),  improving  technical  and  operational  synergies 
between  CPI  and  ICP,  adopting  the  rolling  survey  approach  in  the  region, 
continued improvements in data sources and methodology to estimate PPPs, and 
national accounts valuation of comparison resistant areas such as housing;13 and  
(iv)  training modules on ICP’s technical and operational aspects for NIA staff. 
 
11.  Output  4:  Statistical  capacity  of  participating  national  implementing  agencies

collection, field operations, validation and compilation of ICP data, using ICP tools 
developed by ADB to train NIA staff of participating ADB member economies;  
(ii)  technical and knowledge-sharing regional workshops on the theory and processes

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000,15 which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6 and TASF Others). The key expenditure items are 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA through EROD-SDI, ERCD as the executing agency and will 
serve as the RIA of the ICP in Asia and the Pacific, while the NSOs or identified government 
agencies in the participating ADB member economies will be the NIAs. EROD-SDI will be 
responsible for overall management of the TA including (i) recruiting consultants; (ii) procuring 
goods  and  services;  (iii)  collecting  and  analyzing  regional  data  and  calculating  PPPs;  (iv) 
conducting regional workshops and trainings in participating economies; and (v) working closely 
with relevant ADB departments.16 The TA activities will be implemented from December 2019 to 
December 2023. 
 
14.  The NIAs in each participating ADB member economy will conduct price surveys in 
accordance with appropriate sampling designs to collect nationally representative prices of 
available ICP items.17 As in the 2005, 2011, and 2017 ICP TA projects, the Advance Payment 
Facility (APF) will provide limited seed funds to the NIAs, following ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time), to supplement the costs of 
implementing ICP activities at the national level, strengthen ICP infrastructure, and build capacity 
at the national levels.18 The seed funds will also support expenditures in procuring equipment

19.  Social media and websites. All publications and publishable data will be uploaded and 
disseminated through ADB websites. The project website will additionally serve as an information 
dissemination platform of ICP-related information. Because the ICP will now be a regular project 
implemented in a 3-year cycle, the project website will be developed and maintained with support 
under ICP TA projects. The TA will collaborate with ADB’s Department of Communications (DOC) 
and Office of Information Systems and Technology in maintaining the planned project website 
and disseminating project outputs and data to general and targeted users, in consultation with the 
DOC and using DOC’s potential dissemination channels and social media activities.

10  Appendix 1 
Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1. ICP Regional Governance Framework for Asia and the Pacific established 
1.1 Finalize and agree on framework of partnership with NIAs of participating economies, hold meeting of NIA heads, 
and establish RAB (Q4 2019–Q1 2020). 
1.2 Obtain signed no-objection letters by governments of participating economies (Q4 2019–Q1 2020). 
1.3 Collaborate with the ICP Global Office at the World Bank, ICP Governing Board, Interagency Coordination Group 
on ICP, and Technical Advisory Group (Q4 2019–Q4 2022). 
 
2. ICP survey tools developed and price surveys conducted 
2.1 Update regional item list and product catalogs to conduct price collection surveys in the household and non-
household sectors of participating economies for regional and global comparisons (Q4 2019–Q1 2020). 
2.2 Formulate and review sampling designs for price surveys (Q4 2019–Q1 2020). 
2.3 Prepare ICP survey guidelines and operations manual for implementing the ICP at regional and national levels 
(Q4 2019–Q2 2020). 
2.4 Conduct of price data collection for household items by participating economies (Q1 2020–Q1 2021). 
2.5 Conduct of price data collection for non-household surveys (Q2–Q3 2020). 
2.6 Enter and validate data and submit prices for ICP items by participating economies (Q2 2020–Q3 2021). 
 
3. ICP knowledge products delivered and disseminated 
3.1 Validate average prices submitted by participating economies for ICP items (Q2 2020–Q2 2022). 
3.2 Compute and validate data for unweighted PPPs at the basic heading level (Q2 2021–Q1 2022). 
3.3 Submit GDP expenditure values and weights by participating economies (Q4 2021–Q2 2022). 
3.4 Compute and validate weighted PPPs and PPP-adjusted GDP and major aggregates (Q4 2021–Q2 2022). 
3.5 Prepare and publish the final summary and main reports for the ICP in Asia and the Pacific (Q2–Q4 2022). 
3.6 Prepare and finalize 2020 ICP database and web page (Q2 2021–Q4 2022). 
3.7 Conduct research on ICP-related topics such as subnational PPPs, integration of ICP and CPI price surveys, and 
rolling survey approach (Q1 2021–Q4 2022). 
 
4. Statistical capacity of participating NIAs developed and strengthened 
4.1 Conduct preparatory training workshops, including a regional inception workshop, workshop on updating the 
regional product list, review of sampling designs, and overview of intra-economy validation (Q1 2020–Q2 2020). 
4.2 Conduct periodic regional workshops and technical evaluation and validation workshops and training on ICP 
methods, price statistics, and national account statistics topics related to the ICP (Q2 2020–Q3 2022). 
4.3 Conduct regional workshops, trainings in participating economies, and knowledge-sharing events to strengthen 
statistical capacity of participating economies to institutionalize ICP surveys, develop subnational PPPs, synergy 
between CPI and ICP activities, national accounts improvements from ICP’s perspective in participating 
economies (Q2 2020–Q3 2022).
